ABSTRACT
In today’s context, there is a significant rise in the use of the Internet, and new technolo-
gies keep changing. Traditional networks are having a hard time keeping up with all the
extra use. The emergence of Software Defined Networks (SDN) is pivotal in data centers
and wide area networks, playing a crucial role in next generation network architectures.
SDN is characterized by a decoupled data and control plane with a logically centralized
architecture, posing challenges in controller placement to minimize propagation latency,
which saves time and effort. In SDN, a really important part is the controller. It makes
sure everything runs smoothly and behaves the way it’s supposed to. Determining where
to place the controllers and how many to use is important for how well the network works.
Finding out the best place and getting an efficient number of controllers is crucial to mak-
ing sure the network runs smoothly and stays strong. The proposed Simulated Annealing
approach leverages advanced algorithmic techniques for controller placement, considering
the specific goal of minimizing CC-avg latency. This involves the development of opti-
mization algorithms that dynamically adapt to network conditions and traffic demands.
This research presents a comprehensive and effective approach to controller placement in
SDN, specifically focusing on the minimization of propagation latency.

INTRODUCTION
Software Defined Networking (SDN) transforms how networks are managed by separating
control and data forwarding functions. In SDN, controllers take charge of network-wide
decisions, allowing administrators to program and optimize network behaviour. However,
where these controllers are placed is crucial. It affects how fast data travels through the
network. This is known as the SDN controller placement problem. By figuring out the
best spots for controllers, we can speed up data flow, make better use of resources, and
boost overall network performance. This paper delves into this problem, its importance,
and ways to solve it for smoother SDN operations.
1.1 Software Defined Networks
1.1.1 Introduction
Software-Defined Networking (SDN) changes how we control and manage networks. In-
stead of having one device do all the thinking and sending of data, SDN splits these tasks
[1]. It puts a smart ”controller” in charge of deciding where data goes, while other devices
handle the actual sending. This setup lets us control the network from one central place,
making it easier to adjust how data moves around. It’s like having a traffic control centre
for the internet, making everything run smoother and faster.[12]
1.1.2 Key Components of SDN
(a) SDN Controller : This is a centralized software entity that plays a crucial role
in managing the network. It interacts with network devices to collect information
aboutthenetwork’slayout, traffic, andotherimportantdetails. Aftergatheringthis
data, it makes intelligent decisions and sends instructions to the network devices
accordingly.[11]
(b) APIs (Application Programming Interfaces): APIs serve as communication
channels within the SDN architecture. Northbound APIs link the application layer
with the SDN controller, allowing for the implementation of network policies and
services. Meanwhile, southbound APIs enable communication between the SDN
controller and the infrastructure layer, facilitating the transmission of specific in-
structions to network devices.

1.1.3 SDN Architecture
(a) Application Layer: This layer encompasses various network applications and
business logic that utilize the SDN infrastructure. These applications utilize north-
bound APIs to communicate with the SDN controller, enabling the implementation
of network policies, security measures, and other services. The SDN architecture is
shown in figure 1.1.
Figure 1.1: SDN Architecture [13]
(b) Control Layer : The control layer comprises the SDN controller, which holds a
central role in the SDN architecture. It receives information from the application
layer and employs southbound APIs to communicate with the infrastructure layer.
The controller is responsible for maintaining a comprehensive view of the network,
analyzing data from switches, and making real-time decisions. It translates high-
level network policies from the application layer into specific instructions for the
infrastructure layer.
(c) Infrastructure Layer : Also known as the data plane, this layer consists of net-
work devices such as switches, routers, and access points. These devices handle the
physicalorvirtualforwardingofdatapacketsbasedoninstructionsreceivedfromthe
SDN controller. Communication between the SDN controller and the infrastructure
layer is facilitated through southbound APIs like OpenFlow, which standardizes the
communication between controllers and network devices.

1.2 Controller Placement Problem
The Controller Placement Problem (CPP) is a critical aspect of SDN, focusing on finding
the best locations to deploy controllers within a network infrastructure. Its goal is to
strategically position controllers to efficiently manage and control data flow. Controllers,
responsible for making intelligent decisions to ensure smooth network operation, require
optimal placement for top performance.
Efficient controller placement in SDN significantly impacts the network’s agility, scal-
ability, and overall performance. Controllers centrally manage traffic, enforce policies,
and react to network events, making optimized placement crucial for reducing control
overhead, latency, and ensuring responsiveness.
Solving the Controller Placement Problem (CPP) involves deploying effective strate-
gies to optimize controller placement. Various approaches exist, each with its advantages
and drawbacks. Centralized placement, with a single controller overseeing the entire
network, simplifies management but may affect performance. Distributed placement, em-
ploying multiple controllers strategically, enhances scalability and fault tolerance. Hybrid
approaches combine centralized and distributed elements for a balanced approach. The
aim of Controller Placement Problem (CPP) is to minimize network latency, maximize
throughput, and enhance robustness and fault tolerance.
It primarily addresses three key aspects:
• the number of controllers
• the position of controllers
• and the chosen network topology.
Figure 1.2 shows the various optimal objectives for CPP,The Controller Placement Prob-
lem (CPP) involves strategically positioning controllers in a network to optimize perfor-
mance and minimize costs. This problem is classified based on the network scope (LANs
vs. WANs), controller type (centralized vs. distributed), and optimization objectives
such as traffic load balancing, latency minimization, or cost optimization. Overall, solv-
ing CPP requires balancing technical considerations with practical network demands to
achieve optimal controller placement.

1.3 Latency
Latency, within the Controller Placement Problem (CPP) framework, denotes the tem-
poral gap between initiating a request or action and receiving the corresponding response
within the network. This temporal lag, typically quantified in milliseconds (ms), directly
impacts network efficiency and responsiveness by influencing the speed at which con-
trollers and switches exchange information and make decisions.
In Software-Defined Networks (SDN), elevated latency levels can induce delays in
transmitting and processing control messages between switches and controllers, thereby
slowing down decision-making processes and network responsiveness. Given the impera-
tive of swift adaptation in SDN contexts, minimizing latency becomes pivotal for main-
taining optimal network functionality.[15]
Within SDN environments, two pivotal latency types stand out: Switch-Controller
Latency and Controller-Controller Latency. The former encapsulates delays in commu-
nication between switches and controllers, thereby influencing decision-making processes
and network responsiveness. Conversely, Controller-Controller Latency encompasses de-
lays among multiple controllers, impacting coordination and information dissemination.
Tackling both latency types is imperative for enhancing SDN performance and fostering
efficient network communication.

Average-case latency refers to the typical delay experienced during communication be-

1.4 Clustering
Clustering in the context of SDN refers to the process of dividing a large and complex net-
work into smaller, more manageable segments or domains. These segments are created
by grouping network components, such as switches and routers, into clusters based on
certain criteria or characteristics. The objective of clustering is to improve the efficiency
and effectiveness of network management in SDN environments. Clustering can lead to
more efficient routing and traffic management within each domain. Controllers can focus
on the specific needs of a cluster, optimizing network performance and reducing latency
within that segment. The concept of clustering is often closely related to the efficient
placement of SDN controllers. Controllers can be positioned within or near clusters to
provide more localized control and decision-making, which can help reduce latency and
improve network responsiveness.
Clustering plays a significant role in Controller Placement Problem (CPP) when con-
sidering latency optimization. By employing clustering techniques, controllers can be
grouped together based on network topology, thus enabling more efficient management of
network traffic and reducing latency. This clustering approach allows for the distribution
of controllers in a manner that minimizes the distance between them and the network
components they control, leading to faster response times and improved overall network
performance. Additionally, clustering facilitates load balancing and fault tolerance mech-
anisms, as controllers within the same cluster can collaborate to handle increased traffic
or compensate for failures, ensuring uninterrupted service delivery. Furthermore, cluster-
ing aids in scalability by allowing for the seamless addition or removal of controllers as
network requirements evolve, without sacrificing latency optimization. Clustering strate-
gies within SDN CPP contribute significantly to latency reduction and overall network
efficiency.[16]
1.5 Motivation
The project is driven by the growing importance of Software-Defined Networks (SDN) in
contemporary network architectures, especially in data centers and wide-area networks.
SDN offers the automation of network management tasks, leading to decreased manual
efforts and error reduction. This automation accelerates the deployment of network ser-
vices and ensures optimal resource utilization. Solving the Controller Placement Problem
(CPP) becomes crucial to strategically position controllers within the network, aiming
to optimize resource usage. This involves minimizing latency, lowering communication
overhead, and distributing controller load effectively. The proper placement of controllers
directly impacts network performance.

1.6 Problem Statement
TheControllerPlacementProbleminSoftware-DefinedNetworks(SDN)isanincreasingly
critical area requiring focused attention. It involves determining the optimal number of
controllers needed and their strategic placement within the network. This research intro-
duces a Simulated Annealing-based approach for addressing this challenge. The algorithm
seeks to find the most effective locations for deploying controllers within the SDN infras-
tructure. By leveraging Simulated Annealing, a metaheuristic optimization technique, the
approach aims to iteratively improve controller placement to minimize latency, reduce
communication overhead, and optimize resource utilization. This research contributes
to advancing solutions for the Controller Placement Problem in SDN by proposing an
innovative algorithm based on Simulated Annealing.
1.7 Objectives
The objectives of the proposed work are outlined as follows:
• To calculate the distance between the nodes using Haversian formula.
• To calculate the shortest distance using dijkstra’s algorithm.
• To generate optimal centers by simulated annealing approach in such a way that it
reduces the average propagation latency between controllers.
1.8 Scope
• It is limited to Data plane and Control plane because the switches and controllers
in SDN are located in data and control plane only.
• It only focuses on controller-to-controller average latency.

• The controller localization approach implemented with NMR algorithm has slightly

Disadvantages
• This study was limited to finding the controller placement considering average SC
latency, average CC latency and load balancing. Additionally, this study is limited
to present NMR algorithm as an approach for multi-controller placement over SDN
environment and made a comparison with Bat algorithm.
• Implementing DBCP may require a deep understanding of density-based clustering
methods and network architecture.

The Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) is a systematic approach used by software

tions, defining the software’s architecture, data structures, and user interface elements.
With the design in place, the Implementation phase sees the actual coding of the soft-

where various testing techniques are employed to detect and rectify defects, ensuring the
software meets quality standards. Upon successful completion of testing, the Deployment
phase brings the software into the production environment, ready for use by end-users.
Finally, the Maintenance phase ensures ongoing support, monitoring, and enhancement of
the software, addressing issues as they arise and incorporating new features based on user
feedback and evolving requirements. Effective communication and collaboration among
team members and stakeholders are vital throughout the SDLC, facilitating the smooth
progression of the project and the delivery of a high-quality software product.

CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
In Software-defined Networks (SDNs), the Controller Placement Problem (CPP) involves
to strategically positioning controllers within the network to efficiently manage and con-
trol the underlying infrastructure. A Simulated Annealing based Approach for Controller
Placement in Software Defined Networks (SAA-CP) addresses this challenge by employ-
ing a simulated annealing optimization technique. This approach aims to find an optimal
placement of controllers by iteratively adjusting their positions to minimize latency and
improve network performance.
SAA-CP optimizes controller placement by considering factors such as average-case la-
tency between controllers and network topology. By iteratively exploring different place-
ment configurations and evaluating their performance, SAA-CP efficiently adapts to net-
work dynamics and requirements. The results highlight the effectiveness of SAA-CP in
reducing propagation latency, thereby enhancing the overall efficiency and adaptability
of SDN architectures. For future work, SAA-CP could further enhance its performance
and scalability. By dynamically adjusting controller placement based on latency metrics,
SAA-CP can optimize resource utilization, minimize congestion, and improve network
responsiveness, fault tolerance, and resilience to failures.
